plan_metadata.name: AYAHUASCA INTERMEDIATE
plan_metadata.target_athlete: Intermediate cyclist, time-crunched (3-5 hrs/week), performance-focused finish
plan_metadata.goal: Maximum FTP gains and race-ready threshold power with minimal time investment

workouts.name: W01 Mon - Rest
workouts.description: • Welcome to time-crunched training. You have 3-5 hours per week and want performance, not just completion. This plan uses G-Spot (87-92% FTP) and Threshold (95-105% FTP) because they deliver maximum fitness gains in minimum time. Every minute counts. No junk miles. You'll do 2-3 quality sessions per week with everything else as rest or very light recovery. This is about FTP gains and race pace power—the most important metrics for gravel racing success. • WEEK PREVIEW: Foundation week. Tuesday has FTP test (20 min max sustained effort). Thursday introduces G-Spot intervals (3x10 min). Saturday is tempo endurance (75-90 min). This week establishes your baseline and introduces time-efficient intensity. • REST DAY NOTE: Fine to ride if you really want, but no longer than an hour and don't break 30 TSS.

workouts.name: W01 Tue - FTP Test
workouts.description: • STRUCTURE: 20 min warmup with 3x1 min efforts → 5 min all-out → 10 min recovery → 20 min max sustained effort → 10 min cooldown • Classic 20-minute test. This is HARD but not a sprint—sustainable max effort for full 20 minutes. Pace it: start controlled, hold steady, push final 5 min. Average power × 0.95 = FTP. Write it down. This number drives your training for 12 weeks. Don't sandbag it—you need accurate zones. • CADENCE: Self-selected for test effort.

workouts.name: W01 Wed - Rest
workouts.description: • Full rest day. Testing was maximal effort. Your body needs recovery. • REST DAY NOTE: Fine to ride if you really want, but no longer than an hour and don't break 30 TSS.

workouts.name: W01 Thu - G-Spot Introduction
workouts.description: • STRUCTURE: 15 min warmup → 3x10 min @ 87-92% FTP (5 min easy between) → 10 min cooldown • First G-Spot session. This is "uncomfortably sustainable"—harder than tempo, easier than threshold. You should be able to hold steady power but conversation is difficult. This zone maximizes aerobic gains without crushing fatigue. If you're blowing up, back off 3-5%. Quality matters more than hitting exact watts. • CADENCE WORK: Mix cadences—interval 1 high cadence (100+ rpm), interval 2 low cadence (40-60 rpm), interval 3 self-selected.

workouts.description: • Rest day. Time-crunched training requires disciplined rest. Two quality sessions need genuine recovery between them. • REST DAY NOTE: Fine to ride if you really want, but no longer than an hour and don't break 30 TSS.

workouts.name: W01 Sat - Tempo Endurance
workouts.description: • STRUCTURE: 20 min easy → 3x12 min @ 80-85% FTP (4 min easy between) → 15 min easy • Longest ride of week. Tempo (upper Z3) builds aerobic capacity and teaches your body to sustain power. "Comfortably hard"—you can talk but don't want to. Eat 40-50g carbs during ride. Practice race fueling now. • CADENCE WORK: Mix cadences on tempo blocks.

workouts.name: W02 Mon - Rest
workouts.description: • Week 2 builds on your FTP baseline with more G-Spot work. This zone is your bread and butter for time-crunched training—maximum adaptation per minute invested. You'll do 3 quality sessions this week. • WEEK PREVIEW: Tuesday extends G-Spot intervals (3x12 min). Thursday introduces threshold touch (3x8 min @ 95-100%). Saturday has longer tempo endurance (90 min total). Quality over quantity. • REST DAY NOTE: Fine to ride if you really want, but no longer than an hour and don't break 30 TSS.

workouts.description: • STRUCTURE: 15 min warmup → 3x12 min @ 87-92% FTP (5 min easy between) → 10 min cooldown • Extended intervals. 2 more minutes per interval than last week. Should feel challenging but sustainable. If power drifts >5%, shorten intervals. Building time at this intensity is the key to gravel performance. • CADENCE WORK: Mix cadences—interval 1 high cadence (100+ rpm), interval 2 low cadence (40-60 rpm), interval 3 self-selected.

Pace yourself—interval 4 should be as strong as interval 1. • CADENCE WORK: Intervals 1, 3 at high cadence (100+ rpm), intervals 2, 4 at low cadence (40-60 rpm).

time_crunched_philosophy.description: Time-crunched training (3-5 hours/week) - maximum FTP gains with minimal time investment
time_crunched_philosophy.quality_sessions: 2-3 quality sessions per week, everything else rest or very light recovery
time_crunched_philosophy.principle: Every minute counts. No junk miles.

cadence_work.base_period: High cadence (100+ rpm seated) and low cadence/torque (40-60 rpm seated, big gear) on all intervals
cadence_work.build_period: Mix high/low cadence + rhythm intervals (2 min Z3 + 1 min Z4 patterns) + loaded intervals (1 min Z5/Z6 → settle into Z3)
cadence_work.description: Teaches power production in different ways, foundation for changing pace

rhythm_intervals.description: Alternating patterns: 2 min Z3 (self-selected cadence) + 1 min Z4 (high cadence 100+ rpm) x 3-4, continuous

loaded_intervals.description: 1 min Z5/Z6 (high cadence, seated) → settle into 9-14 min Z3 (self-selected cadence). Simulates race starts and surges.

strength_training.note: Athlete performs own strength program. Suggested on lighter training days. Time-crunched plans prioritize cycling work.

monday_week_preview.description: Monday rest days include week preview with key workouts, time-crunched reminders, FTP gains focus, and race execution guidance

time_crunched_considerations.quality_over_quantity: 2-3 quality sessions per week, everything else rest
time_crunched_considerations.aggressive_rest: Time-crunched = quality over quantity. Save energy for hard sessions.
time_crunched_considerations.ftp_focus: Maximum FTP gains and race-ready threshold power with minimal time investment
